quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Finding product-market fit is the single most important thing that your startup does in the first three years, and it's just underexplored and it's just underexplained as a topic.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Sets a clear priority for early-stage startups and highlights a gap in common startup guidance.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We've published dozens of articles on the First Round Review, and we have found a very consistent set of patterns, demand satisfaction, and efficiency. But the interesting thing is that you don't go for all three of them from the very beginning.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Introduces a practical PMF framework and a counterintuitive sequencing insight about not optimizing everything at once.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: There's essentially four levels of product-market fit: nascent, developing, strong, extreme.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a simple staging model teams can use to diagnose where they are on the PMF journey.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You've got the persona, the problem, the promise, and the product. Lattice kept the first one but changed the others. Vanta changed all four.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Offers a concrete “four Ps” pivot framework with real examples of what to change when stuck.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Roughly, 60% are never going to get past L2.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A sobering data point that underscores how hard it is to progress beyond early PMF stages.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point, your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights a predictable inflection point for SaaS teams: enterprise readiness becomes a customer-driven requirement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Their APIs are easy to understand so that you can ship quickly and get back to building other features.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Emphasizes a practical product-building heuristic: choose tooling that minimizes integration drag to preserve roadmap focus.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Frames experimentation as a core operating system for product decisions, not a nice-to-have analytics practice.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying, prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Gives concrete levers for increasing experimentation throughput: stats methods, self-serve analysis, and automated reporting.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insights with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable growth mechanism: sharing learnings fuels an experimentation flywheel that generates more test ideas.

quotes.topic_title: Todd’s product-to-VC journey
quotes.text: So I am a VC. I'm a partner at First Round Capital now, and I've been at First Round for four years. But I was not a VC before First Round.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights a non-traditional path into venture, reinforcing that operator experience can be a credible route into investing.

quotes.topic_title: Todd’s product-to-VC journey
quotes.text: So I started a company in 2013 called Cover, and that was actually funded by First Round 11 years ago. That's how I got to know First Round.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A concrete example of relationship-building through founder-investor collaboration that later shaped his career transition.

quotes.topic_title: Todd’s product-to-VC journey
quotes.text: So I have always loved product, and that's actually the reason now that I love being a seed stage VC because I love investing at the early stage founders who are pre-product-market fit and then helping them get there. And I just love doing that over and over again.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Captures a repeatable operating focus for seed investing: concentrate on pre-PMF teams and systematically help them reach PMF.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF needs a framework
quotes.text: The thing about product-market fit is that I find it's mysterious to a lot of people, and people tend to think about it purely as an art rather than a science.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Frames the core problem: PMF is treated as intuition-driven, motivating a more systematic approach.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF needs a framework
quotes.text: And all the advice that you find out there on the internet is very general when it comes to product-market fit. You'll know it when you see it, you'll know it when you have it. It's not specific.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Calls out why founders struggle: common PMF guidance is vague and non-operational.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF needs a framework
quotes.text: And I think the reason is because it was specific and because it was tactical and it brought a little bit of the science to something that people thought was just an art.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Explains what makes a PMF methodology resonate: specificity, tactics, and measurable rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF needs a framework
quotes.text: But like you said, product-market fit is the single most important thing that your startup does in the first three years and it's just underexplored, it's underexplained as a topic.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A prioritization heuristic for founders: PMF dominates early-stage outcomes yet lacks clear playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF needs a framework
quotes.text: If you talk to enough successful founders, and in this case, it can be enterprise founders, and you ask them, "What did you do in the first six to nine months of running your company, of starting your company? What patterns emerged from that?" And we have found a very consistent set of patterns, and that's what we decided to base our framework around.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Describes the methodology behind the framework: pattern-mining from many founder retrospectives, especially early months.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF is the top early priority
quotes.text: sometimes it gets lost that actually, the only thing that matters in the first couple years is finding product-market fit and actually, what we define as extreme product-market fit, and I'll go into that.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A contrarian prioritization claim that reframes early-stage execution around a single overriding goal: (extreme) PMF.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF is the top early priority
quotes.text: Because if you find extreme product-market fit, the momentum just carries you, and the market pulls you along.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for PMF as a force-multiplier where demand drives progress rather than constant pushing by the team.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF is the top early priority
quotes.text: And it's easy to know what to build because you're building the thing that your customers want and it's motivating as a team. It's easy to hire people, everything becomes easier if you find product-market fit, it is the thing that propels the company.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on why PMF should come first: it simplifies product decisions, team motivation, and hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF is the top early priority
quotes.text: the hard truth about it is that most of them don't get past the first couple levels of it. The majority of startups do not get past, what we call, level one product-market fit or level two product-market fit.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A sobering observation that introduces a levels-based PMF framework and highlights how commonly startups stall early.

quotes.topic_title: Why PMF is the top early priority
quotes.text: And if they can unlock the right product and the right way to explain it to a customer and make a customer deeply satisfied, and there's enough customers out there like that, it just pulls the whole thing along.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A practical checklist for PMF: right product, clear positioning, deep satisfaction, and sufficient market size.

quotes.topic_title: Who the framework is for
quotes.text: This is for early B2B founders, and specifically founders who are doing something that is more sales-led than bottom-up.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Defines the target audience precisely so founders can quickly decide whether the framework applies to their go-to-market motion.

quotes.topic_title: Who the framework is for
quotes.text: I think bottom-up is its own world. It's closer to consumer product development in my mind.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Offers a mental model that bottom-up B2B behaves more like consumer, implying different PMF tactics than sales-led enterprise.

quotes.topic_title: Who the framework is for
quotes.text: Consumer product, I think there is a little bit more alchemy involved. It's about having great taste and finding the right thing at the right time and it's like catching lightning in a bottle.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Memorably contrasts consumer PMF as less deterministic, setting expectations for how much can be systematized.

quotes.topic_title: Who the framework is for
quotes.text: I think the good thing about enterprise, and specifically sales-led B2B, is that there is more science to it.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Positions enterprise PMF as more methodical and testable, encouraging founders to use structured approaches rather than intuition alone.

quotes.topic_title: Who the framework is for
quotes.text: And so it is for sales-led B2B founders who are in, let's call it, the first six to nine months of starting their company and want to set the foundation for product-market fit right from the beginning.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Gives a concrete timing window and goal—use the framework early to deliberately lay PMF foundations.

quotes.topic_title: What the framework can and can’t do
quotes.text: We can't guarantee success here.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Sets realistic expectations that a PMF framework improves odds but does not promise outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: What the framework can and can’t do
quotes.text: finding extreme product-market fit is very, very hard.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Reframes PMF as an unusually difficult achievement, helping practitioners calibrate effort and timelines.

quotes.topic_title: What the framework can and can’t do
quotes.text: And what we are trying to do is increase your odds, increase the odds, reduce the role of luck, give you a framework and way of thinking about the things that you need to do.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Defines the practical value of the framework: systematically improving probability of success by making levers explicit.

quotes.topic_title: What the framework can and can’t do
quotes.text: I think if you know what the path looks like and you know what the levers are at your disposal and you know what you need to aim for, I think we can get more of these companies to level three and level four product-market fit, which is where you really want to be and where you have a very valuable company.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Offers a mental model of PMF as levels and emphasizes clarity on path/levers/targets to reach the most valuable stages.

quotes.topic_title: First Round’s PMF Method program overview
quotes.text: One of the founders was like, "I feel like these 14 weeks saved me two years of time in what would've been wandering through the desert."
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A concrete beta-program outcome that quantifies how a structured PMF process can dramatically compress learning cycles.

quotes.topic_title: First Round’s PMF Method program overview
quotes.text: So there's eight sessions in the full program, and the first one is the one we're going to do today.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Introduces a structured, multi-session methodology for systematically working toward product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: First Round’s PMF Method program overview
quotes.text: The second one is on customer discovery, and we actually refer to it as dollar-driven discovery.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Names a specific discovery methodology that emphasizes willingness-to-pay rather than generic customer feedback.

quotes.topic_title: First Round’s PMF Method program overview
quotes.text: We get very specific about not just the normal way of doing customer conversations and customer discovery, but how do you find that a customer is willing to pay money for this thing and a lot of money?
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to orient discovery toward high-value demand signals (payment and price level), not just interest.

quotes.topic_title: First Round’s PMF Method program overview
quotes.text: We talk about product iteration and pivots, and I refer to this stage as the grind, the grind of product iteration.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes iteration/pivots as an expected, sustained phase rather than a quick fix.

quotes.topic_title: Time commitment and why it’s free
quotes.text: The way that we think about it is that the program roughly takes about 10 hours a week for each founder, and it's 10 hours of work that you were going to be doing anyway.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Reframes a time-intensive program as simply structuring the core PMF work founders should already be doing.

quotes.topic_title: Time commitment and why it’s free
quotes.text: It is literally you're talking to customers, you're improving your positioning, you're doing critical thinking about your market and what you should be building.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Gives a concrete checklist of the highest-leverage activities to prioritize when searching for product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Time commitment and why it’s free
quotes.text: And so the way I think about it, and the way I've heard from the 11 founders that went through it is it just added structure to what I was doing anyway and it actually made me more efficient.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights the efficiency gain from adding structure to existing work, backed by feedback from 11 founders.

quotes.topic_title: Time commitment and why it’s free
quotes.text: So it's 100% free and literally, it costs you $0. We give you $0, we own 0% of your company.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A clear, memorable statement of incentive alignment that challenges the assumption that programs require equity or fees.

quotes.topic_title: Time commitment and why it’s free
quotes.text: You have to put stuff out in the world that is useful, and if you can create that value, create enough value with the audience, then you'll be able to capture that value at some point.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A value-creation-first mental model for building long-term leverage and relationships without immediate monetization.

quotes.topic_title: Framework overview: definition and PMF levels
quotes.text: So extreme product-market fit is a state of widespread demand for a product that satisfies a critical need and crucially can be delivered repeatably and efficiently to each customer.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A precise definition of “extreme PMF” that adds repeatable, efficient delivery as a core requirement—not just demand and satisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: Framework overview: definition and PMF levels
quotes.text: And so there's three key ideas in there: demand, satisfaction and efficiency. And I think efficiency is worth highlighting because that's what most people would leave out of their definition.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights the commonly missed dimension (efficiency) that determines whether a product can actually work at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Framework overview: definition and PMF levels
quotes.text: Those products managed to achieve customer satisfaction and demand, but they never got the efficiency right, and so the whole business just never worked at scale.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A cautionary lesson that demand + satisfaction can still fail without an efficient delivery/economic model.

quotes.topic_title: Framework overview: definition and PMF levels
quotes.text: And if you have product-market fit, and as you are progressing along this journey, the marginal customer should be getting easier and easier and easier to get, easier to acquire them, easier to give them good service with a good product.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Introduces the “marginal customer” as a practical diagnostic: PMF strengthens when the next customer becomes progressively easier to win and serve.

quotes.topic_title: Framework overview: definition and PMF levels
quotes.text: And along the way, you're trading off these three dimensions: satisfaction, demand, and efficiency because they're intertwined.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A mental model for navigating PMF stages: you must make explicit tradeoffs across demand, satisfaction, and efficiency rather than optimizing all at once.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 nascent PMF and Vanta example
quotes.text: And at level one, your job is to find three to five customers that have a particular problem that is worth solving and to deliver them a satisfying solution.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A crisp, actionable definition of Level 1 nascent PMF with a concrete target (3–5 customers) and the core objective (satisfying solution).

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 nascent PMF and Vanta example
quotes.text: So of the three dimensions that you just recapped, Lenny, it's satisfaction first, demand second, efficiency last when you're at level one.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A prioritization framework for early PMF that helps teams avoid optimizing the wrong thing too early.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 nascent PMF and Vanta example
quotes.text: It's actually okay to be inefficient at this stage if it helps you uncover something that delivers an insanely good customer satisfaction.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that legitimizes manual/inefficient work as a deliberate strategy to maximize learning and satisfaction.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 nascent PMF and Vanta example
quotes.text: And it's one of the clearest examples to me of a product that satisfies a promise, but this product is going to unlock revenue for you.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A memorable lens for evaluating early solutions: they should fulfill a high-stakes promise tied directly to customer revenue outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 nascent PMF and Vanta example
quotes.text: Completely manual. She was the one behind the email address posing as the AI, but doing it herself.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A concrete “Wizard of Oz” example (Vanta) showing how to deliver value before the product is fully built.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 stuck signals and the four Ps pivots
quotes.text: And then there are metrics to track efficiency, things like burn multiple, gross margin, NRR all of these things. All of them are just not applicable at this stage. It's too early and you shouldn't be worrying about that stuff.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Contrarian guidance on ignoring later-stage efficiency metrics when you’re still searching for early product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 stuck signals and the four Ps pivots
quotes.text: And so the yellow flags are something like, let's say, your product disappeared overnight, your customers wouldn't be super disappointed.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A simple diagnostic for weak value: low customer disappointment is a key “stuck” signal at Level 1.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 stuck signals and the four Ps pivots
quotes.text: This is our version of the four Ps. You've got the persona, the problem, the promise, and the product. And all four of these things have to line up. Your product has to deliver a promise that solves the problem of your persona.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A clear pivot/PMF framework that helps teams reason about what to change (and what to keep) when stuck.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 stuck signals and the four Ps pivots
quotes.text: And the response was off the charts. And people wanted this thing. And I believe he sold his first five or 10 customers with Figma mock-ups.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Concrete example showing how strong demand can be validated (and sold) before building the full product.

quotes.topic_title: Level 1 stuck signals and the four Ps pivots
quotes.text: So that's an example of they actually kept a lot of the code that they had written. They kept the product, but they completely changed the other three Ps.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A practical pivot pattern (Plaid) illustrating you can keep the product while flipping persona/problem/promise.

quotes.topic_title: How to choose what to change
quotes.text: I tend to gravitate towards the, "I want to sell it before I build it," because I really want the signal from customers and I want that to be the guide and the oxygen that drives what I'm building.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A clear sell-before-build methodology that uses customer demand as the primary steering mechanism for what to build.

quotes.topic_title: How to choose what to change
quotes.text: Rather than guessing like, "Oh, I'm going to write 50,000 lines of code and then see if somebody wants this thing," I think it's better to talk to a bunch of customers, know that, "Hey, if I had this thing, if I could build this thing, I know it would sell. I know these people want this thing."
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A practical alternative to overbuilding: validate demand through conversations before investing heavily in product development.

quotes.topic_title: How to choose what to change
quotes.text: So I tend to approach it from that point of view and therefore, I focus on the persona and the problem and the promise.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Prioritizes iterating on the first three Ps (who, what pain, and positioning) as the fastest levers to find traction.

quotes.topic_title: How to choose what to change
quotes.text: And then the product's job is to satisfy those first three Ps really.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A crisp mental model: product is downstream of persona/problem/promise, not the starting point.

quotes.topic_title: How to choose what to change
quotes.text: You said it's 20 introductions to one sale, but you're getting them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark for what “nascent” PMF can look like—painful conversion, but real sales signal.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the customer “friend zone”
quotes.text: Rick's analogy, I just love it for level one, is you don't want to get friend-zoned by your customers, where your customers like you, but they don't love you and they don't need you.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for distinguishing polite interest from true product necessity in early customer conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the customer “friend zone”
quotes.text: And his technique for doing this, which I really like, is super simple, was he was very close with his first five or 10 customers.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete early-stage tactic: build deep relationships with a small set of customers to validate real need.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the customer “friend zone”
quotes.text: And he would go to them and sit them down one-on-one and say, "I need your help. It is very important to me that this company succeeds and does not fail. So I don't want you to be nice to me. I want you to tell me is Persona a necessity for your company? If we went away, how painful would that be? If a competitor came along that charged half as much as us, would you switch to them?"
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Provides a verbatim script founders can use to elicit honest feedback and test willingness-to-pay and switching behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the customer “friend zone”
quotes.text: And he's really trying to get to the essence of: is Persona critical for you or am I in the friend zone?
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Summarizes the core diagnostic question behind the approach: critical dependency vs. friendly-but-optional usage.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding the customer “friend zone”
quotes.text: The sooner you know the truth, the better.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that seeking potentially painful honesty early is preferable to prolonged ambiguity about product-market fit.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: "Are we a thing?" I love that. That's so good. The sooner you know the truth, the better. And it's hard to hear bad news, but I love that, just advice of just sit them down one-on-one.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A direct, actionable reminder to seek fast, candid customer truth via 1:1 conversations rather than avoiding negative feedback.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And these pop-ups are becoming less and less effective since most users don't read what they say. They just want to close them as soon as possible.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Challenges the default playbook of relying on in-product pop-ups/tours by highlighting why they fail in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And they do pop-ups too, but their nudges are based on in-product behaviors like confusion or intent classification, which makes them much less annoying and much more impactful.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical methodology: trigger guidance from observed behavior/intent rather than generic announcements to improve effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Yeah. So level two is developing product-market fit, and your job at level two is now you've got to go from five satisfied customers to 25 satisfied customers.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A clear milestone-based framing of the PMF journey that helps founders set concrete targets for the next stage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And so now you've got to start thinking about demand in addition to satisfaction.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A key shift in focus: beyond making users happy, founders must ensure the product can generate pull and scale acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Level 2 developing PMF: scaling to 25 customers
quotes.text: Yeah. So level two is developing product-market fit, and your job at level two is now you've got to go from five satisfied customers to 25 satisfied customers. And so now you've got to start thinking about demand in addition to satisfaction.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Defines Level 2 PMF as a concrete customer-count milestone and shifts the focus from satisfaction to scalable demand generation.

quotes.topic_title: Level 2 developing PMF: scaling to 25 customers
quotes.text: To get to 25 and to get beyond 25, the product has to be doing a lot of the heavy lifting for you.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: A memorable heuristic for when founder-led hustle stops scaling and the product must drive growth.

quotes.topic_title: Level 2 developing PMF: scaling to 25 customers
quotes.text: A benchmark, we would say, is that your sales conversion without a warm intro is still probably 10%, something like that.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Gives a practical benchmark for cold (non-warm-intro) conversion rates at this stage.

quotes.topic_title: Level 2 developing PMF: scaling to 25 customers
quotes.text: You might starting to be thinking about magic number, which is a new ARR that you take in in a period divided by the CAC you spend in that period, so something in the 0.5 to 0.75 range.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Introduces an efficiency metric definition plus a target range appropriate for Level 2 companies.

quotes.topic_title: Level 2 developing PMF: scaling to 25 customers
quotes.text: But we would say you want your gross margin to be not worse than 50%, and you'd want your burn multiple to be not worse than five X.
quotes.speaker: Todd Jackson
quotes.context: Provides clear guardrails for unit economics and burn efficiency even before they become the main focus.
